vignette:
Karmen Fuentes was a 50-year-old married Hispanic woman who presented to the psychiatric emergency room (ER) at the urging of her outpatient psychiatrist after telling him that she had been thinking about overdosing on Advil.

In the ER, Ms. Fuentes explained that her back had been “killing” her since she fell several days earlier at the family-owned grocery store where she had worked for many years. The fall had left her downcast and depressed, although she denied other depressive symptoms aside from a poor mood. She spoke at length about the fall and about how it reminded her of a fall that she had sustained a few years earlier. At that time, she had gone to see a neurosurgeon, who told her to rest and take nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs. She described feeling “abandoned and not cared about” by him. The pain had diminished her ability to exercise, and she was upset that she had gained weight. While relating the events surrounding the fall, Ms. Fuentes began to cry.

When asked about her suicidal comments, she said they were “no big deal”—they were “just a threat” aimed at her husband to “teach him a lesson” because “he has no compassion for me” and had not been supportive since the fall. She insisted that her comments about overdosing did not have another meaning. When her ER interviewer expressed concern about the possibility that she would kill herself, she exclaimed with a smile, “Oh wow, I didn’t realize it’s so serious. I guess I shouldn’t do that again.” She then shrugged and laughed. She went on to talk about how “nice and sweet” it was that so many doctors and social workers wanted to hear her story, calling many of them by their first names. She was also somewhat flirtatious with her male resident interviewer, who had mentioned that she was the “best-dressed woman in the ER.”

According to her outpatient psychiatrist of 3 years, she had never before expressed suicidal ideation until this week, and he would be unable to check in on her until after he left on vacation the next day. Ms. Fuentes’s husband reported that she talked about suicide “like other people complain about the weather. She’s just trying to get me worried, but it doesn’t work anymore.” He said he would never have suggested she go to the ER and thought the psychiatrist had overreacted.

Ms. Fuentes initially sought outpatient psychotherapy at age 47 because she was feeling depressed and unsupported by her husband. During 3 years of outpatient treatment, Ms. Fuentes had been prescribed adequate trials of sertraline, escitalopram, fluoxetine, and paroxetine. None seemed to help.

Ms. Fuentes described being “an early bloomer.” She became sexually active with older men when she was in high school. She said dating had been the most fun thing she had ever done and that she missed seeing men “jump through hoops” to sleep with her. She lived with her 73-year-old husband. Her 25-year-old son lived nearby with his wife and young son. She described her husband as a “very famous” musician. She said that he had never helped around the house or with child-rearing and did not appreciate how much work she put into taking care of their son and grandson.
diagnosis: Histrionic personality disorder

vignette:
Larry Goranov was a 57-year-old man who demanded an expert review of the psychiatric care that he had received for the prior 7 years at a psychiatric clinic connected to a medical school. Mr. Goranov indicated to the clinic’s psychiatric director that he had been depressed for many years, but weekly psychotherapy and multiple different psychiatric medications had made no difference.

Mr. Goranov reported feeling sad, tired, and frustrated “for decades.” He rarely looked forward to anything. He had lost his last job 3 years earlier, had broken up with a girlfriend slightly later, and doubted that he would ever work or date again. He was embarrassed that he still lived with his mother, who was in her 80s. He denied any immediate intention or plan to kill himself, but stated that if he did not improve by the time his mother died, he did not see what he would have to live for. He denied disturbances in sleep, appetite, or concentration.

Clinic records indicated that Mr. Goranov had been adherent to adequate trials of fluoxetine, escitalopram, sertraline, duloxetine, venlafaxine, and bupropion, as well as augmentation with quetiapine, aripiprazole, lithium, and levothyroxine. He had experienced some improvement in his mood while taking escitalopram but did not have remission of symptoms. He also received a course of cognitive-behavioral therapy early in his treatment, but he had been dismissive of the therapist and treatment, did not do his assigned homework, and appeared to make no effort to use the therapy between sessions.

Mr. Goranov expressed frustration at his lack of improvement, the nature of his treatment, and his specific therapy. He found it “humiliating” that he was forced to see trainees who rotated off his case every year or two. He frequently found that the psychiatry residents were not especially educated, cultured, or sophisticated, and thought that they knew less about psychotherapy than he did. He much preferred to work with female therapists “because at least they’re pretty, and men are too competitive and envious.”

Mr. Goranov had worked as an insurance broker from age 25 to 40. He explained, “It’s ridiculous. I was the best broker they had ever seen, but I still can’t get a job. I think the problem is that the profession is filled with big egos, and I can’t keep my mouth shut about it.” After being “blackballed” by insurance agencies, Mr. Goranov did not work for 5 years, until he was hired by an automobile dealer. He said that although it was beneath him to sell cars, he was successful, and “in no time, I was running the place.” He quit within a few months after an argument with the owner. Despite encouragement from several therapists, Mr. Goranov had not applied for a job or pursued employment rehabilitation or volunteer work; he strongly viewed these options as beneath him.

Mr. Goranov has “given up on women.” He had many partners as a younger man, but he generally found them to be unappreciative and “only in it for the free meals.” Psychotherapy notes from the clinic indicate that he responded to demonstrations of interest with suspicion. This tendency held true in regard to both women who had tried to befriend him and therapists who had taken an interest in his care. Mr. Goranov described himself as someone who had a lot of love to give, but added that the world was full of manipulators. He said he had a few buddies, but his mother was the only one he truly cared about. His parents had emigrated from Eastern Europe when he was a child. He had no siblings, and his father had died when the patient was 41. He had met a few relatives over the years, “but they didn’t speak English, so I didn’t pay them much attention.” He enjoyed fine restaurants and “five-star hotels,” but he added that he could no longer afford them. He exercised daily and was concerned about maintaining his body. Most of his time was spent at home watching television or reading novels and biographies.

On examination, the patient was neatly groomed, had slicked-back hair, and wore designer hip-hop-inspired clothing generally favored by men in their 20s. He was coherent, goal directed, and generally cooperative. He said he was sad and angry. His affect was constricted and dismissive. He denied an intention to kill himself but felt hopeless and thought of death fairly often. He was cognitively intact.
diagnosis: Narcissistic personality disorder

vignette:
Mathilda Herbert was a 23-year-old woman referred for psychiatric consultation to help her “break out of her shell.” She had recently moved to a new city to take classes to become an industrial lab technician and had moved in with an older cousin, who was also a psychotherapist and thought she should “get out and enjoy her youth.”

Although she had previously been prescribed medications for anxiety, Ms. Herbert said that her real problem was “shyness.” School was difficult because everyone was constantly “criticizing.” She avoided being called on in class because she knew she would “say something stupid” and blush and everyone would make fun of her. She avoided speaking up or talking on telephones, worried about how she would sound. She dreaded public speaking.

She was similarly reticent with friends. She said she had always been a people pleaser who preferred to hide her feelings with a cheerful, compliant, attentive demeanor. She had a few friends, whom she described as “warm and lifelong.” She felt lonely after her recent move and had not yet met anyone from school or the local community.

She said she had broken up with her first serious boyfriend 2 years earlier. He had initially been “kind and patient.” Through him, she had a social life by proxy. Soon after she moved in with him, however, he turned out to be an “angry alcoholic.” She had not dated since that experience.

Ms. Herbert grew up in a metropolitan area with her parents and three older siblings. Her brother was “hyperactive and antisocial” and took up everyone’s attention, whereas her sisters were “hypercompetitive and perfect.” Her mother was anxiously compliant, “like me.” Ms. Herbert’s father was a very successful investment manager who often pointed out ways in which his children did not live up to his expectations. He could be supportive but tended to disregard emotional uncertainty in favor of a “tough optimism.” Teasing and competition “saturated” the household, and “it didn’t help that I was forced to go to the same girls’ school where my sisters had been stars and where everyone was rich and catty.” She developed a keen sensitivity to criticism and failure.

Her parents divorced during her senior year of high school. Her father married another woman soon thereafter. Although she had planned to attend the same elite university as her two sisters, she chose to attend a local community college at the last minute. She explained that it was good to be away from all the competition, and her mother needed the support.

Ms. Herbert’s strengths included excellent work in her major, chemistry, especially after one senior professor took a special interest. Family camping trips had led to a mastery of outdoor skills, and she found that she enjoyed being out in the woods, flexing her independence. She also enjoyed babysitting and volunteering in animal shelters, because kids and animals “appreciate everything you do and aren’t mean.”

During the evaluation, Ms. Herbert was a well-dressed young woman of short stature who was attentive, coherent, and goal directed. She smiled a lot, especially when talking about things that would have made most people angry. When the psychiatrist offered a trial comment, linking Ms. Herbert’s current anxiety to experiences with her father, the patient said nothing but was visibly upset. After several such instances, the psychiatrist worried that any interpretive comments might be taken as criticism and had to check a tendency to avoid sensitive subjects. Explicitly discussing his concerns led both the patient and psychiatrist to relax and allowed the conversation to continue more productively.

2. Social anxiety disorder

vignette:
Nate Irvin was a 31-year-old single white man who sought outpatient psychiatric services for “lack of self-confidence.” He reported lifelong troubles with assertiveness and was specifically upset by having been “stuck” for 2 years at his current “dead-end” job as an administrative assistant. He wished someone would tell him where to go next so that he would not have to face the “burden” of decision. At work, he found it easy to follow his boss’s directions but had difficulty making even minor independent decisions. The situation was “depressing,” he said, but nothing new.

Mr. Irvin also reported dissatisfaction with his relationships with women. He described a series of several-month-long relationships over the prior 10 years that ended despite his doing “everything I could” and “never getting angry or yelling.” His most recent relationship had been with an opera singer. He reported having gone to several operas and taken singing classes to impress her, even though he did not particularly enjoy music. That relationship had recently ended for unclear reasons. He said his mood and self-confidence were tied to his dating. Being single made him feel desperate, but desperation made it even harder to get a girlfriend. He said he felt trapped by that spiral. Since the latest breakup, he had been quite sad, with frequent crying spells. It was this depression that had prompted him to seek treatment. He denied all other symptoms of depression, including problems with sleep, appetite, energy, suicidality, and ability to enjoy things.

Mr. Irvin initially denied taking any medications, but he eventually revealed that 1 year earlier his primary care physician had begun to prescribe alprazolam 0.5 mg/day for “anxiety.” His dose had escalated, and at the time of the evaluation, Mr. Irvin was taking 5 mg/day and getting prescriptions from three different physicians. Cutting back led to anxiety and “the shakes.”

Mr. Irvin denied any prior personal or family psychiatric history, including outpatient psychiatric appointments.

After hearing this history, the psychiatrist was concerned about Mr. Irvin’s escalating alprazolam use and his chronic difficulties with independence. She thought the most accurate diagnosis was benzodiazepine use disorder comorbid with a personality disorder. However, she was concerned about the negative unintended effects that these diagnoses might have on the patient, including his employment and insurance coverage, as well as how he would be dealt with by future clinicians. She typed into the electronic medical record a diagnosis of “adjustment disorder with depressed mood.” Two weeks later, Mr. Irvin’s insurance company asked her for his diagnosis, and she gave the same diagnosis.
diagnosis:
1. Dependent personality disorder
2. Benzodiazepine use disorder

vignette:
Ogden Judd, a 24-year-old attorney, and his boyfriend, Peter Kleinman, a 22-year-old freelance graphic designer, presented for couples therapy to address escalating conflict around the issue of moving in together. Mr. Kleinman described a several-month-long apartment search that was made “agonizing” by Mr. Judd’s work schedule and his “endless” list of apartment demands. They were unable to come to a decision, and eventually they decided to just share Mr. Judd’s apartment. As Mr. Kleinman concluded, “Ogden won.”

Mr. Judd refused to hire movers for his boyfriend’s belongings, insisting on personally packing and taking an inventory of every item in his boyfriend’s place. What should have taken 2 days took 1 week. Once the items were transported to Mr. Judd’s apartment, Mr. Kleinman began to complain about Mr. Judd’s “crazy rules” about where items could be placed on the bookshelf, which direction the hangers in the closet faced, and whether their clothes could be intermingled. Moreover, Mr. Kleinman complained that there was hardly any space for his possessions because Mr. Judd never threw anything away. “I’m terrified of losing something important,” added Mr. Judd.

Over the ensuing weeks, arguments broke out nightly as they unpacked boxes and settled in. Making matters worse, Mr. Judd would often come home after 9:00 or 10:00 p.m., because he had a personal rule to always have a blank “to-do” list by the end of the day. Mr. Kleinman would often wake early in the morning to find Mr. Judd grimly organizing shelves or closets or cleaning the floor. Throughout this process, Mr. Judd appeared to be working hard at everything while enjoying himself less and getting less done. Mr. Kleinman found himself feeling increasingly detached from his boyfriend the longer they lived together.

Mr. Judd denied symptoms of depression and free-floating anxiety. He said that he had never experimented with cigarettes or alcohol, adding, “I wouldn’t want to feel like I was out of control.” He denied a family history of mental illness. He was raised in a two-parent household and was an above-average high school and college student. He was an only child and first shared a room as a college freshman. He described that experience as being difficult due to “conflicting styles—he was a mess and I knew that things should be kept neat.” He had moved mid-year into a single dorm room and had not lived with anyone until Mr. Kleinman moved in. Mr. Judd was well liked by his boss, earning recognition as “employee of the month” three times in 2 years. Feedback from colleagues and subordinates was less enthusiastic, indicating that he was a micromanager on shared projects, and often critical of his colleagues’ efforts. Also, it seemed he had a reputation as a bore, stemming from a happy hour trivia night in which he had repeatedly questioned the answers his coworkers provided.

On examination, Mr. Judd was a thin man with eyeglasses and gelled hair, sitting on a couch next to his boyfriend. He was meticulously dressed. He was cooperative with the interview and sat quietly while his boyfriend spoke, interrupting on a few occasions to contradict. His speech was normal in rate and tone. His affect was irritable. There was no evidence of depression. He denied specific phobias and did not think he had ever experienced a panic attack. At the end of the consultation, Mr. Judd remarked, “I know I’m difficult, but I really do want this to work out.”
diagnosis: Obsessive-compulsive personality disorder

vignette:
Raven Lundquist (she/her, preferring Raven) was a 24-year-old graduate student in philosophy who presented for a psychiatric evaluation at her brother’s insistence. The two siblings lived together, and the brother threatened to withhold her allowance from a small trust if she didn’t get “some help.”

Raven explained that her brother was worried about her being “sadomasochistic.” In public, he might just say that he was worried that she was an alcoholic and out of control, but she thought he just didn’t like her interest in “BDSM” (bondage, domination/discipline, sadism/submission, and masochism).

She said that she had been in a relationship with Lilly for about a year. The two of them self-identified as queer, a label they found less stigmatizing than “lesbian.” One evening, after an evening of drinking with her brother, Raven told him that she and Lilly enjoyed going to bondage parties, where they would role-play “mistress-slave scenes” in which they would wear tight leather clothing and high heels, and Lilly would whip Raven and call her derogatory or humiliating names. Raven was fine with being seen as a masochist in public, but in private, she generally enjoyed being in charge.

Raven asked the psychiatrist whether he was “the kind of shrink who pathologizes everything? Surely, you’re not like my brother, who gets squeamish about anything related to kink. But that’s his problem, right doctor? Don’t you agree that his concerns are just homophobia?” She asked whether the psychiatrist had read Justine by the Marquis de Sade, “which isn’t as well written as Lolita, but it strikes a chord. By the way, Lilly laughs at my reading choices, calling me an ‘old-school perv.’ ”

On questioning about other BDSM activities, Raven said she sometimes drugged Lilly without Lilly’s knowledge. She found the sense of control to be extremely sexually exciting. Raven said she did not think Lilly would mind if she found out, given that Lilly identified as a sadomasochist and would often let Raven tie her up. Raven admitted that she had secretly drugged previous sexual partners, but that only one had complained about it, and “only when she found photos on my camera.” That lover had broken off the relationship immediately and claimed that she would have gone to the police if the “photos weren’t so embarrassing.”

When asked about her brother’s concern about her alcohol use, Raven immediately said she did “no illegal drugs, no tobacco, not even weed.” Upon further questioning, she did say she might have an alcohol problem. She said she often planned to have a single drink but generally ended up getting significantly intoxicated. She generally got along well with Lilly and her brother, but they often got into verbal fights after everyone had “become really drunk.” She said she often enjoyed her “binges,” with the only problem being that she often missed early morning classes because of hangovers. She had no criminal history.

Raven’s childhood history was notable for having been abandoned by their mother while young. She and her brother had lived with relatives and in foster homes before they had been adopted by a woman whom she referred to as our “intrusive but well-meaning pseudo-mother.” That woman had died the year before, leaving behind a small trust fund for the two of them. Raven had memory gaps from her childhood and thought she might have been sexually molested. “The abuse narrative would make sense, wouldn’t it? But I really don’t remember.” Raven’s medical history was pertinent for having had scoliosis; as a child, she was treated with insertion of a Harrington rod and an extended hospitalization.

Raven described sexual attraction to both men and women but preferred women because “they are typically more submissive.” When she masturbated, and when she drugged sexual partners, she fantasized about “power and control,” particularly about molesting unwilling partners.

She said she felt calm when in sexual control, and when intoxicated, but that she otherwise felt “pretty anxious.” Previous psychiatrists had diagnosed her with generalized anxiety disorder, for which she had been prescribed a benzodiazepine; these were also the medications she used to drug sexual partners.

Raven said she sometimes felt down and depressed but did not think she had ever had a “clinical depression.” While often anxious, she denied ever having phobias or panic. She denied ever feeling suicidal but had sometimes thought about killing the drugged sexual partners, which, “as you surely know, I would never actually do.” She denied obsessions, compulsions, delusions, and hallucinations. She was intelligent and cognitively intact.
diagnosis:
1. Sexual sadism disorder
2. Alcohol use disorder
3. Generalized anxiety disorder (provisional)

vignette:
Terry Najarian, a 65-year-old salesman for a large corporation, presented for a psychiatric evaluation after his wife threatened to leave him. Although he said he was embarrassed to discuss his issues with a stranger, he described his sexual interest in women’s undergarments in a quite matter-of-fact manner. This interest had surfaced several years earlier and had not been a problem until he was caught masturbating by his wife 6 weeks prior to the evaluation. Upon seeing him dressed in panties and a bra, she initially “went nuts,” thinking he was having an affair. After he clarified that he was not seeing anyone else, she “shut him out” and hardly spoke to him. When they argued, she called him a “pervert” and made it clear that she was considering divorce unless he “got help.”

Mr. Najarian’s habit began in the setting of his wife’s severe arthritis and likely depression, both of which significantly reduced her overall activity level and specifically her interest in sex. His “fetish” was the bright spot during his frequent and otherwise dreary business trips. He also masturbated at home but generally waited until his wife was out of the house. His specific pattern was to masturbate about twice weekly, using bras and panties that he had collected over several years. He said that intercourse with his wife had faded to “every month or two” but was mutually satisfying.

The patient had been married for over 30 years, and the couple had two grown children. Mr. Najarian had planned to retire comfortably later that year, but not if the two choices were either “to be poor after we split the assets or to sit around the house all day and be called a pervert.”

He became visibly anxious when discussing his marital difficulties. He described some recent difficulty falling asleep and “worried constantly” about his marriage but denied other psychiatric problems. He had made a show of throwing away a half dozen pieces of underwear, which had seemed to reassure his wife, but he had saved his “favorites” and “could always buy more.” He said he was of mixed mind. He did not want to end his marriage, but he saw nothing harmful in his new mode of masturbating. “I’m not unfaithful or doing anything bad,” he said. “It just excites me, and my wife certainly doesn’t want to be having sex a few times a week.”

Mr. Najarian denied any difficulties related to sexual functioning, adding that he could maintain erections and achieve orgasm without women’s undergarments. He recalled being aroused when he touched women’s underwear as a teenager and had masturbated repeatedly to that experience. That fantasy had disappeared when he became sexually active with his wife. He denied any personal or family history of mental illness.

vignette:
Vance Orren was a 28-year-old self-reported cisgender heterosexual man who was arrested after pushing a stranger in front of an oncoming subway train. He told police that he believed the man was going to “tell everyone that I was a faggot” and that he, Mr. Orren, was trying to protect himself from the “homosexual conspiracy.”

Mr. Orren had a history of a psychotic disorder, a cocaine use disorder, and nonadherence to medication and psychotherapy at the time of the incident. He was unemployed. In court, Mr. Orren entered a plea of not guilty by reason of mental disease (the “insanity defense”) and underwent a full psychiatric evaluation, including assessment of his sexual history and desires.

As part of his legal case, Mr. Orren underwent a structured sex offender evaluation. He reported that his first sexual contact was at age 12, when his uncle and an 18-year-old male cousin “did things” to him while he was in foster care. They would take him to McDonald’s afterward, “so it was fine.” By the time he was 14 or 15, he was regularly having sex with males and females who ranged in age “from about ten to in their thirties.”

He was unable to answer whether the sexual contact was always consensual, saying, “No one ever called the cops.” As an adult, he said that he preferred having sex with “young girls, because they don’t fight much.” He said that he usually only had sex with adults when he hired prostitutes or prostituted himself in exchange for money or drugs, although he said that sometimes when high, he “might have done stuff that I don’t really remember.”

The structured sex offender evaluation included penile plethysmography, assessment of visual reaction time using Viewing Time (a measure of the amount of time a person looks at a particular photo or other visual representation of a sexually stimulating situation), and a detailed interview about his sexual practices. This evaluation concluded that his main sexual attraction was to girls between the ages of 8 and 13 years.

Mr. Orren’s personal history was significant for multiple childhood disruptions that led to his moving into the foster care system at age 7. At age 9, his first foster mother caught him repeatedly stealing toys and bullying other children. When she reprimanded him, he hit her with a brick, knocking her unconscious. That led to placement in a second foster home. He began using drugs and alcohol at age 11. He was first incarcerated at 13, for shoplifting from an electronics store in order to obtain money for marijuana. At that point, he went back to live with his maternal grandmother, who has episodically provided him a home since then. During those 15 years, he has been arrested at least a dozen times, mostly for drug possession.

Mr. Orren stopped attending school in eighth grade, at about the same time that he was admitted to his first psychiatric inpatient unit. That admission was triggered by his beating his head against a wall “to stop the voices.” He was given a DSM-IV diagnosis of psychosis not otherwise specified, treated with risperidone, and discharged after 1 week. Soon after discharge, he discontinued the antipsychotic medication.

Between the ages of 15 and 28, Mr. Orren regularly abused cocaine and alcohol and often used other substances when they were available. By the time of his arrest, he had had at least seven psychiatric admissions, always for auditory hallucinations and persecutory delusions (usually of a sexual nature). It was not clear which substances he was using prior to and during these episodes of psychosis or whether they were implicated in the development of his psychiatric symptoms. He had also been admitted twice for alcohol detoxification after he went into withdrawal while unable to acquire alcohol. He was consistently nonadherent to any type of outpatient treatment. He maintained sobriety only while in hospitals or jails. When contacted by the consulting psychiatrist, his grandmother pointed out that Mr. Orren had always been “reckless, dishonest, and angry. I don’t think I’ve ever heard him apologize. I love him, but he probably belongs in jail for lots of reasons.”

vignette: Leroy is a 34 year old male, whose chief complaint is, “I am having intrusive thoughts.” Leroy reports that “since childhood, I have been experiencing intrusive thoughts.” He reports he has met with a number of psychiatrists in the past, and has tried a range of different psychiatric medications. Leroy reports he was recently recommended by his present physician to see a psychiatrist again, given how distressing his intrusive thoughts have become. His previous psychiatrist started him on Zoloft, and gave him recommendation for community based mental health psychotherapist.  Leroy has been taking the Zoloft (200 mg daily) for about 5 years, for what he states his provider thought was “anxiety or depression.” Leroy acknowledges history of periods of “sadness”, stating “yeah sad, sometimes, but not depressed; when things get out of control; its been a while though; when something feels out of reach.” Denied present or past suicidal ideation, and denied problems with active thoughts, plans or intents of harm to self or others. Leroy insists no problems with perceptual distortion or paranoia, and denied thought insertion or thought broadcasting.  Leroy stated that the intrusive thoughts, “first started happening when I was a kid, I was able to cope with them; getting better understanding what they were; ways to get them to go away; calm myself down and regain control and go on with my life; now that is not working.” Leroy states the most recent intrusive thought has been a fear that the chart bus he drives from his local airport to downtown stop will “slide off the road because of ice or snow.” He thinks about this, on average, about 30 to 45 minutes a day.  Leroy endorsed episodes of “panic” and “my body almost feels like its paralyzed; I experience pain from my spine up”, which lasts for a couple of days at a time. With regards to “generalized anxiety”, patient reports “I would have these thoughts about my ailing mother; she has schizophrenia; my body would react to whatever I was thinking about her; my body tenses up when that happens.” Leroy denied any preoccupations about his physical health, nor inability to leave the home because of anxiety. He reports to work regularly, and rarely misses any work unless he is very sick. He says he is never late to work or planned appointments. Leroy has a girlfriend, and says that relationship is going “great.” In his spare time, he continues to join his friends for basketball pickup games and video game nights, which he still enjoys. Leroy does remember a feeling of having to tap the door handle a few times before he opens it, but said this never lasted more than a few second and was not associated with any fear of catastrophic consequences if he did not complete the task.  Leroy acknowledges observed violence/abuse of his parents when growing up, and with harsh parenting to his 3 siblings, patient denied problems with flashbacks, nightmares or hypervigilance associated with the trauma. Patient works second shift, gets home around 1:30 a.m., reports falling asleep at 2:30 a.m. and wakes up at 10/11 a.m., and can typically sleep through the night without interruption. He reports his energy level is “normal through the week.” Denied recent or past mania. Reports contributing stressors are “work --- not the most peaceful environment.” Also reports mother suffers from “type of schizophrenia and for a while she was taking medication and just recently now decided to stop; that’s been going on for quite some time.” Leroy’s urine toxicology returned with marijuana, and TSH level was within normal limits.

vignette: Emil is a 22 year old male that reports “my mom wanted us to meet because she spent her whole first therapy session talking to another therapist at her new program about how she feels I need help; I suspect it has to do with my multiple sclerosis (MS), recently losing my fiancé (Lizzy), and after loosing my dog that came with my fiancé. I also lost my career as a farmer.” The patient reports “My girlfriend and I had a good relationship when I used to be able to fish with her; she was a blue blood from the Cape.” Patient reports that he survived being “attacked when I was at a local bar about 4 years ago; the guy smashed a few beer bottles on my head; I had to go to the hospital and they did brain scans; I don’t remember what they said they found.” Patient reports that after that attack, he stopped fishing and started drinking alcohol heavily, at least 8 standard drinks per day, resulting in him missing work, the end of his relationship with his girlfriend, and resulted in getting two DUIs. Patient remembers, “I tried cutting down, but I was never able to do it.” The patient has been sober from alcohol for 76 days now. He denied any other drug use. Patient reports that around two years ago, “I was starting having another MS flare, I stopped being able to sleep for about two weeks and felt angry all the time.” Patient reports during that time he took several last minute trips to Baltimore by train, trying to start a new business and during that time had many sexual indiscretions. He states “people said I was acting strange and that I claimed I was a celebrity that was going to find a cure for autism.” Emil states “I felt like I had endless energy and could take on the world.” The patient reports no similar episodes like that since then, and denied any major mood symptoms since that time. Emil denied recent or past hallucinations, paranoia or thought insertion. Emil reports he never experienced trauma, with the exception of losing his girlfriend and dog. The patient denied any recent problems with depressed, sad, or hopeless mood, and denied problems recent problems with decreased need for sleep and associated elevated energy, racing thoughts, pressured speech or feelings of euphoria. He denied recent or past anxiety or panic, nor OCD.
diagnosis: Bipolar disorder, most recent episode manic, in remission (F31.74), Alcohol use disorder, initial remission (F10.21), Mood disorder due to a known physiologic condition with manic features (F06.33)
model_thoughts:
**Clarifying bipolar disorder codes**

In the DSM-5, I need to choose codes for substance/medication-induced bipolar disorder based on the specific substance. For example, alcohol-related codes could be F10.14 for alcohol abuse with mood disorder, but I’m uncertain about the exact mania code. Medication-induced disorders might be coded as F06.33, which refers to mood disorders from known physiological conditions but not specifically from medications like steroids. This is a bit tricky with overlapping categories!

**Creating differential diagnoses**

I realize that medication-induced conditions are too complex, so I'll focus on more supported differentials. For instance, I can consider Posttraumatic Stress Disorder from assault, even without symptoms, and Mild Neurocognitive Disorder from traumatic brain injury due to head injury. Also, Adjustment Disorder and Persistent Depressive Disorder are worth mentioning. 

Let’s outline some differentials:  
1. Alcohol Use Disorder, moderate (F10.20).  
2. Bipolar I disorder, full remission, most recent manic episode (F31.74).  
3. Bipolar disorder due to another medical condition with manic features (F06.33).  
4. Mild Neurocognitive Disorder due to TBI (G31.84 or F06.7).

**Determining appropriate F-codes**

I see that the user requested only F-codes, which makes things clear. For mild neurocognitive disorder due to TBI, I need to remember that its code is G31.84, which doesn't fit the criteria. The DSM-5 has codes for neurocognitive disorders, and major ones like Alzheimer's also have G codes. 

However, I can include postconcussional syndrome, which has the F-code F07.81. That's important since it qualifies as a mental condition resulting from brain damage!

**Reviewing neurocognitive disorder codes**

I’m realizing that the DSM-5 includes "Mild neurocognitive disorder due to traumatic brain injury," but it complicates things because it has a G code (G31.84), which isn’t allowed. I could consider alternatives, like "Personality change due to another medical condition," but there's no supporting evidence for that. 

Listing "Postconcussional syndrome" as a differential (F07.81) is possible, even though it's not a DSM-5 diagnosis. I’m also noting that "Major neurocognitive disorder due to TBI" does have an F-code, specifically F02.81. That seems like a viable option!

**Choosing psychiatric diagnoses and codes**

I need to summarize relevant codes and diagnoses based on the user's requirements. F02.81 applies to dementia with behavioral disturbance, which may complicate things; major neurocognitive disorder due to TBI could use F02.81 as well. However, I should focus on F codes for mood, anxiety, and trauma.

Top considerations for diagnosis:  
1. Alcohol Use Disorder, moderate (F10.20)  
2. Bipolar I disorder, full remission, most recent manic episode (F31.74)  
3. Bipolar disorder due to another medical condition, with manic features (F06.33)

vignette: Neveah is a 14 year old girl that comes to her pediatrician with her mother (presently 4 months pregnant) due to “out of control behaviors at home.” The patient appears restless in the exam room and requiring redirection from her mother throughout the visit. The patient frequently punches her mother in the legs, and in the stomach, and the patient even threw her ipad at the pediatrician when she asked the patient what was upsetting her. Most of the patients psychiatric history is gathered from her mother, given how irritable the patient is during the exam. The mother reports Neveah was born 8 weeks pre-mature, spent about 1 month in the neonatal intensive care unit due to problems with breathing, and ultimately discharged home to her care at one month of age. The patient met developmental milestones on or near expected time, and was “clingy” when she was a toddler, but had no problems making friends in daycare and grade school. When patient was about 11 years of age, her biological father left the home to join the military, and has deployed ever since. Around 12 years of age, around summertime, the patient appeared much more talkative, energetic, and would go several days only needing about 3 hours of sleep at night. She was more impulsive during these times, and believed she had super powers to “make her friends get in trouble at school”, even when she was not at school herself. She was never tired the following day. During that same period, she had many temper tantrums throughout the day, almost every day of the week, that seemed disproportionate to circumstances, like having to have a peanut butter and jelly sandwich instead of a peanut butter and fluff sandwich. The tantrums would last several hours in a day. This pattern of behavior would last for several weeks at a time, with periods of months returning to normal mood and behavior. The patient never appeared to be hallucination or responding to internal stimuli, and never appeared sad or depressed. Neveah had to be hospitalized during an episode like this when she was 13 years old. Neveah refuses to take medications for her symptoms. The start of this year academic year, that patient appeared more calm and in good behavioral control, but began to have similar symptoms of irritability, violence at home, not needing to sleep, talking fast, and property destruction at home.

vignette: Elain is a 63 year old mother of 5 children and 12 grandchildren, that presents to urgent care with a chief complaint of “I’m hallucinating.” Elain reports no history of depression or manic, and was in her usual state of health until 27 days ago when she witnessed a pedestrian be struck by a moving vehicle in her neighborhood. Elain tried to rescue the pedestrian, and even helped paramedics the responded to the scene provide chest compressions to the pedestrian. Unfortunately the pedestrian was pronounced dead on the scene. Since then, Elain has felt a sense of “dread” and “anxiety” everyday, and feels like every time she hears a cars wheels skid in the street, “I jump out of my skin.” The patient also reports that, when at work, she will have these persistent images of the pedestrian laying in the street, and “I just can’t get the images out of my head.” Elain reports that wakes two or three times a night with nightmares related to the event. Additionally, Elain herself has avoided drying, for fear she will be involved in a car accident herself. She was at work today and decided to come to urgent care because “I was hallucinating” and “I was at my desk and suddenly felt like my body separated from my mind, and I could see myself sitting at my desks, as if I was hovering from above.” Patient denied disorganized speech, thought insertion or thought broadcasting. She denied visual or auditory hallucinations.

vignette: A 19 year old male comes to his primary care off reporting “I think someone has poisoned me at home.” The patient reports that about two and a half months ago, after he lost his job at a local arcade, he started noticing that he was feeling more sleepy at home. He states “I would go to bed around 7 p.m., right after dinner, and not wake up until about 12 p.m. the next day.” He reports before that time, he would go to bed around 10:30 p.m. and wake for work around 6 a.m. He states, “I started to notice that my mom would take longer preparing my plate of food for dinner, and I felt sleepy right after.” He endorsed associated low energy, low motivation and problems with concentration starting around that time. Patient goes on to say “over the past two months, every afternoon when I wake up, I can hear my parents whispering through the vents of the house, planning on killing me and replacing me with a different person.” Patient states he will sometimes also “hear them whispering when I’m at the store getting food and stuff, even though they are all the way back at home.” The patient reports that when he logs onto his ipad to play video games, “I can tell that some of the other characters of the game are my parents pretending to be other people. They are trying to get into my head.” The patient reports over the past 3 weeks he has stopped eating dinner, remains withdrawn to his room, and keeps the shades drawn “because I don’t want them looking into my windows.” The patient denied any other similar periods of symptoms like this in the past, denied illicit substance use (patients urine toxicology returns negative of all substance), and denied recent head injury or seizure. He denied active thoughts, plans or intents of harm to self or others. There are no guns in the home. About halfway through the exam, that patient grabs his jacket and runs out of the doctors office stating “forget it, I can tell you are working with my parents to kill me too.

vignette: Stacy is a 54 year old Navy Veteran that comes to the emergency room complaining of “I feel like bugs are crawling all over me.” Patient reports this started about 36 hours ago after returning home from an elective surgical procedure (the patient had a ‘tummy tuck’). Following her surgeons orders, the patient has been on bed rest, abstaining from heavy activity. The patient reports “I also feel incredibly thirsty and I’m shaking like a leaf.” She denied any recent head trauma, and denied history of strokes or seizures. She lives alone in an apartment downtown. She I’ve lost a lot of friends over the years, so I mostly just stay home and delivery food if I’m hungry.” She reports “I have 4 or 5 beers a day”, stating she does not drink more than that “because I’ve been taking Klonopin for about 15 years and those two things do not mix.” The patient does admit, “my PCP stopped prescribing my Klonopin about a year ago, so I buy them from an online dispensary.” She acknowledges sometimes having a beer and Klonopin in the morning, “just to keep the shakes down.” On chart review, you see that the patient has also gone to several local emergency rooms over the past 2 years, with urine toxicology positive for alcohol, benzodiazepines, opiates and amphetamines, although in the controlled substance prescribing database, you see that the patient has never been prescribed opiates or amphetamines. Upon further questioning, that patient does acknowledges she has tried cutting back on alcohol use, since her family and friends has said “it seems like its taking over my life.” Unfortunately, she has not achieved any lengthy sobriety, and has actually found she is drinking more over the past year to achieve a similar effect. Blood labs on this visit indicate severely low sodium and potassium. Patient denied visual hallucinations, auditory hallucinations and denied sad or depressed mood.

vignette: Collin is a 71 year old man, with remote history of alcohol use disorder, but has been sober for about 6 years. He used alcohol heavily from about 28 years of age to 65 years of age, acknowledging multiple inpatient medical hospitalizations for acute alcohol withdrawal as well as medical complications due to alcohol use, including acute liver failure and subsequent permanent gait abnormalities. He has come to his PCP with his wife reporting, “my family thinks I’m changing.” The wife interrupts the patient and states “you are changing, Collin.” The wife discloses that the patient wandered out of the house into the cold 3 times over the past month, and in the middle of the night. The wife states “I found him outside at about 2 a.m., it was 4 degrees outside and he was in his boxers, just standing there.” The patient himself recalls his wife bringing him inside, but can’t recall going outside. A recent CT scan in the local emergency room indicated no acute abnormalities or indication of stroke. The wife goes on to say, “Collin used to love cooking for the family, but now he can’t find his way around the kitchen”, stating the patient forgets to turn the burners off on the stove and even causes a fire in the kitchen a couple of months ago. The wife reports the family started noticing these changes about 2 years ago. There is no family history of dementia, Parkinson’s or Huntington’s disease. There are no known falls. Collin ultimately discloses “I do feel depressed these days”, reporting a worsening of sad and depressed mood starting about 2 years ago. He endorsed low motivation, anhedonia, and has even had passive suicidal thoughts over the past month. He denied any recent stressors, and denied returning to drinking alcohol or any drug use. vignette: Patient reports "there was an abrasive attack on my life and I was scared; I went into the emergency room; I let my case manager know I was being harassed by my neighbors; people outside of the community; I tried to let as many people know as possible so I could be safe." Patient reports alcohol use disorder history, associated pancreatitis, with increased drinking recently due to "stress of moving and not being able to be with my dog." Patient reports "I came here to get rest." Reports heavy drinking since 12 years of age, with some sobriety on weekends in early 20's. Reports has recently been drinking 3 of the tall boy beers and "a little brandy." Last drink 5 days ago, but reports has been trying to cut back on drinking over the past 2 weeks. One remote seizure when stopped drinking in the past, but more commonly has shaking and "throwing up non stop." Reports "I hear things; its due to harassment; no one else would know", endorsing some negative commentary auditory hallucinations, which started happening about 2 weeks ago. Denied visual hallucinations, but endorsed thought insertion. Patient reports harassment of "voices of old people that I know from Berlin in High School." Patient acknowledges history of depression, with associated anhedonia, withdrawal, low motivation, decreased appetite and problems with concentration, as well as feelings of isolation, including over the past 3 weeks. Denied problems with active thoughts, plans or intents of harm to self or others. Acknowledges trauma history, not disclosing details, with associated flashbacks, nightmares and hypervigilance, and “I avoid going to bars now.”  Patient acknowledges period about 2 years ago of decreased need for sleep with associated elevated energy, racing thoughts, pressured speech and "I was taking care of my mother going through chemotherapy", which resulted in her being involuntarily hospitalized for about 2 weeks. model_thoughts:
**Analyzing psychiatric diagnoses**

The question involves psychiatric diagnoses, specifically including alcohol use disorder. In a typical inpatient evaluation, the primary diagnosis could be Alcohol-induced psychotic disorder, particularly with auditory hallucinations. While the immediate presentation is psychosis due to alcohol, we should also consider the timeframe: AH began experiencing issues two weeks ago, increasing her alcohol intake due to stress. She last drank five days ago, which could suggest possible alcohol withdrawal hallucinations. However, the onset appears to have started while she was still drinking, complicating things.

**Evaluating alcohol-induced psychosis**

Alcohol hallucinosis can occur either during heavy intoxication or after sudden cessation, usually within 24 hours but can last up to 48 hours or even longer. Alcohol-induced psychotic disorders can start during intoxication or withdrawal and may continue for up to a month post-cessation. In this case, it seems plausible given the decreased use over the last two weeks. The presence of thought insertion and persecutory delusions about neighbors suggests a more severe psychosis, likely pointing to alcohol-induced psychotic disorder, considering the history of bipolar mania too.

**Assessing potential diagnoses**

The symptoms point toward a few possibilities. While there’s been a depressed mood for about three weeks, it may not fully qualify as a major depressive episode, although there is a history of depression. PTSD symptoms are present too. I also wonder if alcohol withdrawal might complicate things, given the last drink was five days ago and a remote seizure occurred. Based on this, I think "Alcohol-induced psychotic disorder, with hallucinations" (F10.251) could be the best primary diagnosis, considering the strong history of alcohol use disorder.

**Determining diagnosis codes**

In the DSM, I would diagnose both Alcohol Use Disorder (AUD) and alcohol-induced psychotic disorder. While the ICD-10 codes may overlap, I could code both as F10.20 (severe AUD) and F10.951, but F10.251 already encompasses both. However, with only five diagnoses allowed, I might list them separately for clarity. The primary diagnosis could be "Alcohol-induced psychotic disorder with hallucinations" (F10.251) and the secondary diagnosis could be "Alcohol use disorder, severe" (F10.20). vignette: Erin is a 16 year old girl that was brought to her pediatric for a routine health exam. Erin is a sophomore at the local high school, plays lacrosse and does ballet at the local arts theatre. Erin reports that she has had no problems with depressed, sad or hopeless mood symptoms, and denied problems with excessive worry or panic. She lives at home with her two mothers, older brother and their dog Fiji. The patient does report that she goes to the gym for about 3 hours each day of the week, during which she does about 2.5 hours of cardiovascular training. She states she skip lunch on most days, has a sliced apple for breakfast, and take her dinner to her bedroom to slowly eat the vegetable portion of dinner (only) over a period of about 3 hours. Menarche was at age 13.5, but she has missed 3 of her last periods. She reports a lot of gastric reflex, and its wakes her up at night time. She also reports “I don’t really have bowel movements anymore, so I take a laxative in the morning and at night time.” She aims to eat less than 1000 calories in a day.

vignette: Amber is a 37 year old woman, that comes to the emergency room with a chief complaint of “I just want to die.” Amber is well known to this emergency room, sometimes coming to the emergency room with suicidal thinking and plans more than 10 times a week. She reports “constant” flashbacks, nightmares, and hypervigilance, and now avoids any places where “Im the only woman in the room.” The patient reports her current suicidal thoughts and plan to overdose on all of her medications at home is due to “my girlfriend broke up with me out of the blue; she said I’m too much to handle.” The patient reports present mood of “pissed off”, but denied any recent problems or changes in appetite, energy, motivation or enjoying activities she typically enjoys. vignette: Evan is a 62 year old white man, a Harvard Professor in Economics, with a multi-decade history of heavy alcohol use, but recently sober for approximately 7 months after completing substance rehabilitation in an outpatient settings. Evan presented to the emergency room after taking approximately ten 1 mg Klonopin in one setting, he states was “because I was tired and really wanted to go to sleep.” The patient indicates “I was not trying to kill myself” and “I regret taking that number of tablets at once.” He acknowledges recent discord with his wife, stating “I feel very afraid that she is going to leave me whenever we get into arguments, also indicating that after their most recent argument 2 days prior, he relapsed with alcohol use and drank about 6 standard drinks each of the last 2 days, and was intoxicated at the time of overdose. Patient reports “I used to be so active in teaching at Harvard. Now, I feel like I don’t have purpose”, stating that his department at Harvard has been assigning him less teaching or supervising obligations. The patient denied problems with active thoughts, plans or intents of harm to self or others. He denied recent or past symptoms of mania or psychosis. The patient acknowledged recent increased need for sleep, up to 14 hours a day, and still feeling tired when awake. He has had a approximately 10 pound unintentional weight loss over the past month. He acknowledges that there has been a significant increase in difficulty concentrating on texts he used to be able to attend to without issue. He states “sometimes it feels like I’m walking through mud throughout the day”, and “I want to get back to enjoying things in life again.” He acknowledges “sometimes I find myself just crying, but I have no idea why.” He denied feelings of hopelessness or despair. He denied trauma history, nor symptoms of OCD or panic. On arrival to the emergency room, patient acknowledged that he sustained a fall at home, which lead to his coming to the emergency room for evaluation. The patient is noted to have left peri-orbital ecchymosis and small, well-healing abrasions to his forehead. A head CT in the emergency room reveal a 2-3 mm subdural hematoma. The patient denied headache or vision changes in the emergency room. The emergency room clinician completed paperwork for the patient to be admitted on an involuntary basis to inpatient psychiatry. The following day, a repeat head CT revealed the subdural hematoma appeared 5-7 mm in length, yet the patient continued to deny vision changes, headache, confusion or extremity weakness. The patient reports he has been taking Cymbalta for a history of depression for over 5 years, and denied an untoward side effects.
diagnosis: Major depressive disorder, moderate, recurrent F33.1; Alcohol use disorder, severe
difficulty: Medium given patient minimizing extent of depression and that overdose was suicide attempt, although endorsing neurovegetative, cognitive, motivation, etc symptoms of depression.

vignette: Melanie is an 11 year old girl who was brought to urgent care by her mother after being sent home from school for “using racial slurs.” Melanie is the product of a full-term, uncomplicated pregnancy, vaginally delivered with normal APGAR (Appearance, Pulse, Grimace, Activity, Respiration) score at birth. Melanie used her first word “Momma” around 48 months of age, and didn’t start noticing other children playing with her until about 6 years old. Even at 6 years old, Melanie would not respond to her name when called, often appearing like she was in a daydream, and would often do a lot of “rocking” or “spinning” when anxious. Melanie’s mother indicates “Melanie is a unique kid. She doesn’t really make good eye contact with me, her father or her friends, and seems to be overly focused on doing puzzles all day. She has a hard time making friends, because all she wants to do is work on puzzles, and does little interactive play with others.” Melanies mother also indicates “if we take her puzzle away from her for dinner, she will have a complete ‘meltdown’ and be inconsolable for a good hour, ultimately leading to us having to give her the puzzle back.” Around 8 years of age, Melanie was found blinking her eyes repeatedly, and would say “I have to do it” whenever family questioned the eye blinking. The eye blinking slowly went away, but seemed to be replace by Melanie contorting her neck repeatedly, and especially when getting ready for school or leaving the house. Now, Melanie slaps herself in the head repeatedly when stressed, to the point that family has to adorn Melanie with soft gloves so she does not cause injury. About 13 months ago, Melanie start screaming out racial slurs when in the grocery store and school, and this would last for about 5 minutes in duration, until she was able to calm down. Otherwise, Melanie denied problems with sad, depressed or hopeless mood, nor problems with auditory or visual hallucinations. Melanies mother denied observations of bizarre rituals such as excessive handwashing, counting or organizing, but does report Melanie has a strong and persistent interest in puzzles. Melanie denied active thoughts, plans or intents of harm to self or others.

Mom reports that about 2 weeks ago the patient’s father lost his job unexpectedly, and the family is now going to have to move to a new state to find new work. The patient reports feeling much more tired during the day now, even after getting about 10 hours of sleep each night. Mom states “if he is not sad and crying, he is angry and kicking me”, acknowledging patient has engaged in some light property destruction at home and bullying his younger siblings.

vignette: Patient is a 59-year-old female with an unassessed complex trauma history presenting with not-just-right sensations related to hair and bumps growing on her face that cause substantial distress, despite acknowledging that the hairs and bumps are not always physically present. To manage this distress, she keeps tweezers on her person at all times, checks mirrors every 30 minutes when at home, and avoids staying home for extended periods. She also exhibits contamination concerns manifesting as excessive handwashing (25+ times daily) and using barriers to avoid direct contact with "unclean" surfaces out of fear of contracting an illness. Patient believes that she must act on her physical sensations or contamination-related thoughts most of the time or the distress will persist. Patient also collects items like My Little Ponies and Trolls. She has filled her home, garage, basement, a rented warehouse, and now pays to store items in a neighbor's garage despite saying she has little to no money to pay for these expenses. She expresses strong attachment to these possessions, stating she would "NEVER" sell them, and has a history of repurchasing items she previously attempted to sell. Patient's medical history is significant for AIDS (diagnosed 2003, currently on Odefsey), and past surgical interventions following a car accident. Her psychological history includes previous diagnoses of PTSD and Bipolar Disorder (which she disputes). Current symptoms of a major depressive episode include anhedonia, restlessness, sleep disturbance (averaging 4 hours nightly), feelings of worthlessness, and difficulty concentrating. These episodes emerge roughly every few month. The patient denied symptoms of psychosis as well as symptoms related to higher than usual energy or goal-directed activity at any time in the past. She endorsed suicidal ideation without current plan or intent, rating likelihood of attempt at 1%. Social support is reportedly limited, with the patient living alone with her two dogs, having infrequent contact with her daughter, and minimal social connections beyond casual acquaintances while shopping. She denied distress or functional impairment resulting from any traumatic events.

vignette: The patient is a 25-year-old male who presented with delayed responses and was vaping during intake. He currently works full-time managing his hot tub repair company and lives with his girlfriend. His medical history includes multiple substance addictions, particularly opioids (requiring Suboxone and later Methadone treatment), and previous diagnoses of OCD, ADHD, anxiety disorder, and depressive disorder. He reports a significant history of head trauma (8 concussions), one seizure episode while incarcerated, and multiple incarcerations for offenses including gun possession, burglary, and vehicle theft. His psychiatric medication history includes Adderall, Concerta, Zoloft, an unspecified antidepressant, and Trazodone. The chief complaint involves symptoms that began at approximately age 18 during his first incarceration and have intensified in the past year, coinciding with work stress. Problematic behaviors include arranging items in specific places with extreme rigidity (unable to buy new items that don't have a "place"), performing rituals in sets of three, and a specific handwashing ritual. He experiences intrusive thoughts about harming others (particularly fears of stabbing, shooting, or raping strangers) and engages in compulsive behaviors (brushing his hand from hairline to ear three times) to alleviate associated anxiety. He also reports persistent checking behaviors due to memory doubts, a need for things to feel "just right", and specific ordering rituals. Additionally, he endorses current anhedonia, decreased appetite, fatigue, and concentration difficulties that wax and wane every few months. He shared that these symptoms are distressing, though mildly impairing in his social, work, and leisurely activities. He denies current suicidality, self-harm, or hallucinations/delusions. He reports a childhood history of conduct problems (skipping school, lying, stealing, fighting) and adult behaviors including illegal activities, irresponsibility, deceitfulness (e.g., using fake identifications) and reported guiltlessness after harming others or damaging property. His childhood conduct problems (e.g., fighting) have resulting in the concussions reported in the medical history, and his illegal activities have resulted in two incarcerations. When asked about one such activity (stealing a car), he reported no remorse, instead blaming the victim for calling the police. The assessment revealed that these behaviors have continued for years in multiple settings, though as of late, he reported that he has not engaged in any illegal activities because he does not want to return to jail for a third time.

Unwanted thoughts include fears of transmitting sexual fluids to others (which he believes would make him "a rapist"), concerns about accidentally killing insects, moral distress about consuming animal products, and beliefs that viewing violent media constitutes "condoning" violence. vignette: Patient is a 47-year-old female residing in the Northeastern United States who recently lost her job due to alleged "disorganization", which she contests as the actual reason for termination. Currently unemployed but financially stable for the near term, she is pursuing employment opportunities abroad with plans to relocate to Vietnam in September 2021. The patient lives alone with no local support system and has recently withdrawn from her social connections following concurrent stressors of job loss and the death of her pet cat, expressing irritation with friends' "bad advice". She denies substance use, maintains good physical health aside from requiring iron supplementation, and reports a childhood head injury at age 11 without loss of consciousness. Patient describes longstanding organizational tendencies dating back to approximately age 8, recalling precise block stacking and meticulous desk organization throughout her schooling. These behaviors were particularly pronounced during her high school years when her family sponsored relatives' citizenship, resulting in 16 people residing in her home. She demonstrates consistent contamination-related behaviors, including using barriers when touching public surfaces, frequent hand sanitization (predating the pandemic), and immediate cleaning of any perceived contamination. The patient engages in regular cleaning throughout the day, reporting an inability to tolerate "a single dirty dish in the sink" and an immediate need to address any uncleanliness she observes. Notably, she denies these behaviors cause distress or any impairment, stating she "enjoys" cleaning and maintaining organization. Patient reported persistent depressed mood, anhedonia, restlessness, fatigue, and feelings of worthlessness over the past two weeks, but said that these symptoms are manageable. She denies current or past suicidal ideation. While she denies feeling "up", "high", or "hyper", she describes persistent irritability manifesting as social withdrawal and increased argumentativeness, characterizing herself as "more lucid" than others because she doesn't "follow the script". She denies symptoms consistent with mania or hypomania, including grandiosity, decreased need for sleep, pressured speech, racing thoughts, distractibility, or increased goal-directed activity. The patient acknowledges experiencing an unspecified "extremely traumatic event" but denies re-experiencing it in distressing ways. Assessment ruled out panic disorder, social anxiety disorder, substance use disorders, psychotic disorders, eating disorders, and generalized anxiety disorder.

vignette: Patient is a 24-year-old gender fluid individual with a BA in creative writing and sociology who is currently living with their parents while taking courses part-time and seeking employment. They describe their living situation as "overwhelming" due to parental boundary issues, though they maintain a supportive romantic relationship since 2019. Their psychiatric history includes diagnoses of MDD and GAD at age 15-16, PTSD in 2016 following emotional abuse by high school friends, and ADHD in 2018 (without neuropsychological evaluation). Current medications include Lisdexamfetamine 50mg (since 2018), various supplements, and a contraceptive injection. They previously tried multiple antidepressants (2011-2015) but discontinued each after approximately two weeks due to suicidal ideation and, in one case, motor disturbances. The patient consumes alcohol socially (3-5 drinks monthly) and has been vaping marijuana 1-3 times weekly for three months primarily to aid sleep and manage anxiety. The patient's primary symptoms onset around age 5 with intrusive visualizations of falling down stairs along with perfectionism through rewriting notes until they felt "just right". Currently, they experience significant distress when surroundings are not in the "right spot", spending up to 12 hours reorganizing belongings without breaks, which would cause severe distress if interrupted. This "not just right" feeling impairs their ability to meet deadlines, complete job applications, and fulfill social obligations. They also engage in checking behaviors when packing (counting socks repeatedly, checking for essential items) and experience distressing sexual intrusive thoughts. Additionally, the patient exhibits skin-picking behaviors, spending over an hour picking at ingrown hairs until bleeding, scratching their neck and jaw during conversations, and tearing at cuticles, with symptoms worsening during periods of anxiety. They've attempted to stop by wearing pants constantly but have been unsuccessful. The patient has a significant history of depression with three past suicide attempts (overdoses in 2014, 2015, and 2017) and self-injury through cutting (stopped in 2017). They currently experience passive suicidal ideation, anhedonia, decreased appetite, sleep difficulties, psychomotor agitation, feelings of worthlessness, and concentration problems, though they report 0% chance of self-harm in the next three months. Social anxiety manifests as persistent fear of judgment and rejection, with distressing rumination about social interactions and excessive reassurance-seeking that has cost them friendships. The patient also reported past sexual abuse by a boyfriend for 4-5 months but denied PTSD symptoms. They disclosed a history of binge eating episodes. During the binge, they ate more rapidly than normal and felt disgusted and embarrassed after. After these eating binges, pt fasted for ~3 days. These eating binges occurred <1 time per week, and the patient has not engaged in these behaviors in the past 2 months.

vignette: The patient is an 18-year-old non-binary college freshman with a complex psychiatric presentation. They report a history of childhood anxiety, perfectionism, and ritualistic self-punishment behaviors starting in the third grade. Currently, their most debilitating symptom is anxiety about "contaminated air" when others cough or sneeze, prompting them to cover their face and hold their breath even when the trigger is far away or on television. They engage in checking and counting behaviors based on the number 3, including checking mirrors while driving, locking/unlocking their car, and tapping their toothbrush. These compulsions are experienced as uncontrollable, with the patient reporting they sometimes modify behaviors (like holding an imaginary door handle in their pocket) when the original compulsion would be disruptive. At approximately age 16, the patient developed anorexia nervosa, restricting their food intake and ultimately requiring intervention from parents and a treatment team. Despite gaining weight under external pressure, the patient continues to restrict eating, has a distinct fear of gaining weight, becoming fat, fasting until dinner, drinking coffee to intentionally upset their stomach. Their BMI currently falls within the normal range. Around the same time their eating disorder developed, the patient experienced depressive symptoms including hopelessness, low motivation, and self-harm behaviors (pulling hair, cutting, punching stomach). They had suicidal ideation during high school, including thoughts of jumping in front of a train and fantasizing about wandering into hallways during a school shooting. Current suicidal thoughts are less frequent and persistent. Current depressive symptoms have been subsyndromal (though not entirely absent) for about 7 months. Specifically, the patient currently denies experiencing depressive symptoms for more than a few hours every couple of weeks but rates their chance of self-harm in the next three months at 50% (suicide attempt chance at 0%). vignette: The patient is a 22-year-old female from the Southeastern United States with a history of Depression (2019), Anxiety (2019), and OCD (March 2021). She recently transitioned from working as a childcare specialist to self-employment as a freelancer. Her medical history includes anemia and IBS, for which she takes daily iron supplements. The patient previously attempted treatment with Zoloft (10mg) for OCD symptoms but discontinued due to emotional blunting effects. She reports consuming alcohol 1-2 glasses a few times monthly and using marijuana daily when available, which she finds helpful for intrusive thoughts despite occasionally triggering anxiety. The patient's most distressing symptoms involve intrusive thoughts about sexually harming children, accompanied by physiological responses that she describes as "groinal". These thoughts were particularly distressing during her work as a childcare specialist, where she engaged in compulsive staring at children's genital areas to "prove" she wasn't sexually attracted to them and sometimes avoided changing diapers due to fear of sexual arousal. After experiencing an intrusive dream about sexually harming her brother in January 2021, she experienced physical symptoms (shaking, freezing) when interacting with him and subsequently increased their time together as a form of reassurance. Additionally, the patient reports significant health anxiety focused on getting cancer, HIV, and STIs, leading to excessive symptom research. The patient experiences panic attacks (1-2 times monthly) lasting 15-30 minutes when triggered by intrusive thoughts, with symptoms including shortness of breath, crying, sweating, racing heart, chest pain, and feelings of detachment. She reports seeking reassurance from her mother when these thoughts become overwhelming. The patient also endorses distressing and functionally impairing social anxiety in small groups, leading to significant avoidance; however, she stated that this anxiety is primary due to her unwanted/intrusive thoughts rather than a fear of being judged. She reports experiencing over 50 depressive episodes in the past year, each lasting at least two weeks with symptoms including decreased appetite, sleep disturbance, fatigue, guilt, concentration difficulties, and thoughts of death. She described these episodes as challenging to manage, but "not completely debilitating".
diagnosis: OCD, mild, fair insight, with panic (F42.2); Illness Anxiety Disorder (F45.21); Major Depressive Episode, recurrent, moderate (F33.1)

vignette: Erik is a 10-year-old male who recently completed 4th grade in a gifted math program. He lives with his biological parents and seven-year-old brother, with whom he has "constant" conflict including arguing, screaming, and hitting. Erik has a developmental history of severe temper tantrums prior to age 4, with behavioral challenges emerging in kindergarten and worsening in subsequent grades. His mother reports that her son engages in "constant defiance", experiences rapid mood changes, and demonstrates impulsive behavior, including occasional incidents of pulling knives (though never pointing them at anyone). Daily arguments at home frequently escalate to physical aggression, particularly with his mother and brother. Erik has expressed statements such as "I wish I could go to sleep and never wake up" and reports feeling depressed "randomly" a couple times per month since second or third grade, though he denies daily depressive symptoms or changes in sleep or appetite. Erik's behavioral difficulties have manifested in both home and school environments. In school, he has engaged in speaking out of turn, refusing to follow directions, agitating teachers, and having "screaming matches" with staff. Despite these challenges, Erik maintains high grades across subjects (with math being his most difficult class at a B), has several friends, and is described as a leader in social interactions. He has a Section 504 plan that allows for movement opportunities and frequent breaks when needed. In March 2019, Erik began taking 2mg of Guanfacine (extended release) for attention/concentration deficits, which has helped reduce impulsivity and improve behavioral control, though aggressive and defiant behaviors have continued. His mother reports implementing a point system for rewards and consequences but notes limited effectiveness due to inconsistent expectations between parents. Formal assessment indicates that Erik demonstrates a pattern of emotional dysregulation, defiance, and aggressive behavior, with physical aggression occurring approximately every other day at home. Assessment also confirms prior symptoms of inattention, hyperactivity, and impulsivity, which are present across settings and contribute to emotional dysregulation and academic underperformance relative to ability.
diagnosis: Oppositional Defiant Disorder, Moderate (F91.3); Attention-Deficit/Hyperactivity Disorder, Combined Type (F90.2)

vignette: Dole is a 31-year-old male who arrived for intake with an extensive psychiatric history dating back to age 17, with multiple hospitalizations and diagnoses including Mood Disorder NOS, Bipolar Disorder, Narcissistic Personality Disorder, Schizoaffective Disorder, and Asperger's Syndrome. His symptoms have included paranoid ideation, auditory and visual hallucinations, delusions (such as believing television was sending special messages), obsessive thoughts, compulsive behaviors, and periods of mania and depression. Dole holds a master’s degree in computer science and previously developed cybersecurity systems but resigned in 2019 due to unmanageable anxiety. He currently lives with his parents, who provide significant assistance with daily activities. Throughout his treatment history, Dole has demonstrated paranoid thoughts beginning at age 19, with recurrent episodes of acute psychosis requiring hospitalization. In 2018, he experienced hallucinations of messages on his phone, and in 2019, he reported seeing "the devil" and experiencing auditory hallucinations. He endorses unwanted/intrusive thoughts causing anxiety, which he attempts to neutralize with repetitive behaviors that take 1-3 hours daily. His symptoms include fear of harming himself, violent imagery, concerns about germs, and moral preoccupations. Dole reports deficits in procedural and episodic memory, impairing self-care and accurate recollection of past events. His family history is positive for paternal psychosis, depression with possible bipolar disorder, and a completed suicide. Intake impressions indicate that Dole has experienced (and continues to experience) delusions, hallucinations, disorganized/catatonic behavior, diminished emotional expression, and amotivation within a one-month period. He has exhibited delusions or hallucinations for at least two weeks in the absence of major mood episodes, and his functioning has decreased notably compared to his pre-symptom baseline. Regarding his unwanted/intrusive thoughts, he demonstrates limited insight.
diagnosis: Schizophrenia, Multiple Episodes, Currently in Acute Episode (F20.9); Obsessive-Compulsive Disorder, Poor Insight (F42.2)
